description:
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 1 is a strain of the Hepatitis C virus, which is a small, enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Hepacivirus genus within the Flaviviridae family. HCV genotype 1 is the most prevalent and widely distributed genotype of the virus, accounting for approximately 46% of global HCV infections.

HCV genotype 1 is further classified into two major subtypes, 1a and 1b, which have distinct genetic and epidemiological characteristics. HCV genotype 1 is known to be more resistant to certain antiviral treatments compared to other genotypes, making it a challenge for clinical management.

The genome of HCV genotype 1 consists of approximately 9,600 nucleotides, encoding a single polyprotein that is subsequently cleaved into 10 individual viral proteins, including the structural proteins (core, envelope 1, and envelope 2) and non-structural proteins (p7, NS2, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, NS5A, and NS5B). These proteins play crucial roles in viral entry, replication, and assembly.

Understanding the molecular and epidemiological features of HCV genotype 1 is essential for the development of effective diagnostic tools, antiviral therapies, and public health strategies to combat the global burden of Hepatitis C infection.
